titleStmt.title: A confidence framing effect: Flexible use of evidence in metacognitive monitoring

analytic.title: A confidence framing effect: Flexible use of evidence in metacognitive monitoring

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Human behavior is flexibly regulated by specific goals of cognitive tasks. One notable example is goal-directed modulation of metacognitive behavior, where logically equivalent decisionmaking problems can yield different patterns of introspective confidence depending on the frame in which they are presented. While this observation highlights the important heuristic nature of metacognitive monitoring, computational mechanisms underlying this phenomenon remain elusive. We confirmed the confidence framing effect in two-alternative dot-number discrimination and in previously published preference-choice data, demonstrating distinctive confidence patterns between "choose more" or "choose less" frames. Formal model comparisons revealed a simple confidence heuristic behind this phenomenon, which assigns greater weight to chosen than unchosen stimulus evidence. This computation appears to be based on internal evidence constituted under specific task demands rather than physical stimulus intensity itself, a view justified in terms of ecological rationality. These results shed light on the adaptive nature of human decision-making and metacognitive monitoring.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Humans' decision behavior usually entails a metacognitive insight into the correctness of their decision, referred to as subjective confidence. Subjective confidence is known to play key roles in guiding one's behavior, such as learning (Boldt, Blulndell, & De Martino, 2019;Guggenmos, Wilbertz, Hebart, & Sterzer, 2016), information seeking (Balsdon et al., 2020;Desender et al., 2018), and error monitoring (Yeung & Summerfield, 2012). Given its importance in navigating adaptive behavior, an active debate has revolved around the underlying mechanisms of how humans construct their confidence (Kepecs & Mainen, 2012;Pouget et al., 2016;Rahnev & Denison, 2018;Webb et al., 2023).

One actively discussed topic is whether confidence is computed under optimal statistical norms or relies on simpler heuristics (Adler & Ma, 2018;Aitchison, Bang, Bahrami, & Latham, 2015). The optimal confidence indexes a faithful readout of the posterior probability of a decision being correct (Meyniel et al., 2015;Pouget et al., 2016;Sanders et al., 2016).
On the other hand, heuristic confidence considers computationally less demanding approximations of decision correctness (Maniscalco et al., 2016;Zylberberg et al., 2012).

Importantly, studies have demonstrated notable discrepancies between subjective confidence and actual decision correctness, suggesting that the calculation of confidence may not be entirely optimal (Kiani et al., 2014;Koizumi et al., 2015;Odegaard et al., 2018;Samaha et al., 2017;Samaha & Denison, 2022).

Recently, Sepulveda et al. (2020) reported a critical piece of evidence supporting the heuristic perspective on confidence. In their experiments, participants performed twoalternative dot-numerosity discrimination and preference choice tasks. These tasks were organized under positive or negative decision frames. For instance, in the dot discrimination, participants were asked to decide which of two stimuli contained larger (or smaller) numbers of dots in the positive (or negative) frame condition. The sum and difference of two stimuli's values were reported to affect participants' confidence, and critically, the condition associated with a greater (or lesser) sum led to increased confidence under the positive (or negative) frame.

The reversed pattern of confidence cannot be captured by the optimal view of confidence since both decision frames present logically equivalent problems, indistinguishable under optimal statistical norms. The framing of decision problems would influence participants' perspectives on the presented information (De Martino et al., 2006;Tversky & Kahneman, 1981), thereby affecting heuristic processes of confidence construction.

This confidence framing effect highlights the critical non-normativity in confidence construction, suggesting that confidence is a flexible entity calculated according to specific decision-making goals. Nevertheless, additional investigation would be warranted to gain a deeper understanding of this phenomenon. Specifically, there is a potential caveat in considering the sum and difference of stimulus values as computational foundations for deriving confidence, despite their frequent use in previous studies (e.g., Brus et al., 2021;Folke et al., 2016;Mazor et al., 2023).

While the sum and difference variables are ignorant of the choice outcome, accumulating evidence has revealed that confidence is well described by the combined effects of chosen and unchosen stimulus evidence (e.g., Maniscalco et al., 2016, Zawadzka et al., 2017Zylberberg et al., 2012). Importantly, chosen evidence is typically assigned greater weight than unchosen evidence in confidence formation, which is shown to be an ecologically rational heuristic for efficient metacognitive monitoring (Maniscalco et al., 2021;Miyoshi & Lau, 2020;Peters et al., 2017).

We have hypothesized that the confidence framing effect, previously attributed to the total value of stimuli, can reasonably be explained by the emphasized contribution of the chosen stimulus value. For instance, the value of the chosen stimulus is higher in the condition of the greater sum value, leading to greater confidence in choosing the "more" stimulus. On the other hand, the value of the chosen stimulus is lower in the condition of the lesser sum value, which leads to greater confidence in choosing the "less" stimulus.

To test this hypothesis, we have conducted an online experiment and compared two confidence rules that may lie behind the confidence framing effect (Figure 1). Under the diffsum rule, confidence derives from the two underlying variables that only consider the physical quantity of stimuli and are ignorant of the observer's decision outcome: the difference and the sum of stimulus values (Figure 1a). On the other hand, under the chosen-unchosen rule, confidence is based on the two variables that are informed of the observer's decision outcome: the chosen stimulus value and the unchosen stimulus value (Figure 1b). Note that this rule does not dictate that confidence is calculated only after a decision has been reached.

Research has demonstrated that confidence can be influenced by both pre-and postdecisional processes (e.g., Pleskac & Busemeyer, 2010;Shekhar & Rahnev, 2018;Xue, Zheng, Rafiei, & Rahnev, 2023). Thus, the chosen-unchosen rule only stipulates the underlying confidence variables and remains agnostic of the specific time course of confidence formation.

Participants performed two-alternative forced-choice (2AFC) tasks, where they compared the number of dots presented within two options. They made choices under two different decision frames: participants were instructed to choose the option with the larger number of dots under a more frame, whereas they needed to choose the one with the smaller number of dots under a less frame. Subsequently, for model comparison, we have regressed confidence data with the underlying variables assumed by the diff-sum and chosen-unchosen rules. In addition, to enhance the robustness and generalizability of the present study, we also conducted model comparisons using the data previously published by Sepulveda et al. (2020).

These comparisons would provide valuable insights into the flexible calculation of confidence in response to varying decision-making demands. confidence derives from the chosen stimulus value and the unchosen stimulus value, where β1 and β2 denote the coefficients for the corresponding variables.

div.head: Material and methods
div.p: We employed an online 2AFC task of dot numerosity discrimination accompanying a 4-point confidence rating. Participants were recruited via an online crowdsourcing service Yahoo! Crowdsourcing and engaged in the experiment via Pavlovia server. The experiment was approved by the ethical committee of the Graduate School of Informatics at Kyoto University. Sample size, data exclusion criteria, hypotheses, and analysis plans were preregistered on AsPredicted (https://aspredicted.org/937_1GB), as of August 1, 2022. As described in the preregistered protocol, participant recruitment persisted until a valid sample size of 30 individuals was achieved. The sample size was determined considering our time and financial limitations in accordance with the guidelines in Lakens (2022). Behavioral data and R codes for analyses are available on GitHub (https://github.com/yosukesakamoto/Framing_Confidence_2023).

div.head: Exclusion criteria
div.p: Data from participants that met any of the following four criteria were excluded: (a) Participants who never reported the lowest or the highest levels of confidence throughout the experiment, (b) Participants who reported the same level of confidence for more than 50% of entire trials, (c) Participants who made a choice within 250 ms after the stimulus onset for more than 10% of entire trials, and (d) Participants who chose incorrect options for more than 40% of entire trials. We applied the above exclusion criteria until we obtained a valid sample size of 15 participants for each framing condition. During the recruitment, 21 participants were excluded under the more frame, whereas 27 participants were excluded under the less frame.
We also set trial-wise exclusion criteria, specifying that trials with a response time below 250 ms or above 10 s would be excluded. However, no trials were found violating these criteria.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Data from 30 participants were used in subsequent analyses (23 males, 6 females, and 1 participant who did not provide a gender response; aged 27-65, mean = 44.37, SD = 9.65). Informed consent was obtained from all the participants. The participants were separately recruited for the two framing conditions on the online platform (15 participants for each). The two framing conditions were labeled as experiment A or B, ensuring that participants were unaware of the critical purpose or manipulation of our research. Participants could choose which experiment to participate in, and the online system prohibited duplicate participation in both experiments. All participants were paid 750 yen for their participation.
Participants whose task accuracy exceeded 75% earned additional rewards of 200 yen. The experiment lasted 45 minutes.

div.head: Stimuli
div.p: All stimuli were presented on a black background. In each trial, white dots, each covering 0.15° of visual angle, appeared within two white-rimmed circles of a radius of 6° for dot number discrimination. Dots were placed on randomly chosen grid points within the circles for each trial. Each circle was placed on either side of the screen and 6.5° distant from the center. To examine how confidence is modulated by stimulus values, we set three baseline levels for the number of dots (50, 100, and 150). The dot numerosity for one of the presented stimuli was always selected from the baseline levels. We manipulated the numerosity of the other stimulus in proportion to each baseline level so that the expected task difficulty would be constant across the baseline levels: Weber's law (e.g., Fechner, 1948;Tsouli et al., 2022).

Namely, the number of the other stimulus was adjusted in 2% increments over 20 steps, spanning from -20% to +20% relative to each baseline level (there was no trial in which the same number of dots were presented within two circles). This ends up in a total of 60 patterns of stimulus values (20 relative numerical differences from the three baseline levels). Each pattern was presented four times throughout the experiment and the left-right presentation 6 positions of the stimuli were counterbalanced across trials.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Prior to the experiment, we obtained the resolution of the participants' screens using a Screenscale procedure (Morys-Carter, 2023) so that stimuli should be presented in equal sizes on each participant's screen. Participants first underwent a practice session consisting of a minimum of 10 trials. Participants were able to repeat the practice session as many times as they deemed necessary before progressing to the main experiment. In the main experiment, they completed six blocks of 40 trials. The experiment was programmed using PsychoPy 3 version 2022.2.3 (Peirce et al., 2019). Figure 2 illustrates the flow of one trial. At the beginning of each trial, a white fixation cross of 1° appeared on the center of the screen for 500 ms. Then, dots were presented for 600 ms within the two circles. Participants who were assigned to the more frame were asked to choose the circle that contained more dots, while those who were engaged in the less frame were asked to choose the circle that contained fewer dots. They were instructed to respond by pressing the left or right arrow key as fast as possible. There were no time limits for making a response, and they were allowed to respond even after the dots disappeared. Following the response, participants were asked to report their confidence in making the correct choice on a 4-point scale. Participants were encouraged to use all rating scales throughout the experiment. There was no time limit for reporting their confidence. The inter-trial interval was set at 500 ms.

div.head: Analysis
div.p: We first conducted hierarchical logistic regressions to analyze choice proportion, and then performed hierarchical linear regressions to explain confidence (for response time analyses, see Figure S2 in Supplementary Material). In analyzing confidence rating data, we primarily focused on the comparison between the diff-sum and chosen-unchosen rules of confidence. Under the diff-sum rule, we used the difference and the sum of the stimulus values as independent variables. On the other hand, under the chosen-unchosen rule, we used the chosen stimulus value and the unchosen stimulus value to explain confidence.

To ensure the orthogonality of the independent variables, we made a logarithmic transformation for each stimulus value (e.g., the original raw scale involves a positive correlation between the diff and sum variables since the stimulus values are defined in proportion to the three baseline values). The application of the logarithmic scaling aligns with the classical framework of psychophysics and offers natural interpretability. For instance, the difference between log-transformed stimulus values corresponds to the ratio of raw stimulus values, which is the determinant of decision difficulty according to Weber's law (e.g., Fechner, 1948;Green & Swets, 1966). After the log-transformation, for better model convergence in statistical analyses, we standardized relevant variables (confidence, diff value, sum value, chosen value, and unchosen value) across all participants.

Under each confidence rule, we constructed eight hierarchical linear regression models that differed regarding fixed-and random-effect terms. These models can be classified in terms of their fixed-effect structures (four types) and their inclusion of random slopes (two types; see Table A1 for more details). We separately applied these 16 models to the data obtained from each framing condition. Model comparisons were based on Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) and Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC). All p-values reported below were adjusted within each regression model using the Bonferroni method, considering all possible main effects and interactions. All analyses were conducted on free statistical software R (version 4.3.0) and all hierarchical models were constructed using lme4 package (Bates et al., 2015). Following the choice, they reported confidence in their choice on a 4-point scale.

div.head: Current behavioral experiment
div.p: First, to ascertain the validity of the experimental manipulation, we constructed psychometric functions to depict the probability of choosing the right-side stimulus based on the value difference, defined by subtracting the logarithm of the left-side value from that of the right-side value. The analysis was implemented as a hierarchical logistic regression with the difference of log-transformed values, decision frame, and their interaction as fixed effects.

Additionally, random slopes were included for the difference of log-transformed values and decision frame. We found a strong interaction effect (z = 20.23, adjusted p < .001), which signifies a reasonable slope reversal according to the decision frames (Figure 3a). Besides, there was no significant difference in mean choice accuracy across participants between the more frame (71.0%) and the less frame (72.6%; χ 2 (1) = 1.38, adjusted p = 1), suggesting that participants in both framing conditions engaged in decision-making, appropriately comprehending their assigned task demands (for more detailed analyses of decision accuracy, see Appendix C and Supplementary Material).

To evaluate the occurrence of the confidence framing effect, we next examined the influence of the summed stimulus value on confidence in the less and more frames. We performed a hierarchical linear regression on confidence with baseline numerosity, decision frame, and their interaction as fixed effects. The analysis also included random slopes for baseline numerosity and decision frame. We found a significant interaction between baseline numerosity and decision frame, which represents the changing effect of the sum value between the decision frames (t(30.00) = 5.23, adjusted p < .001; Figure 3b). Namely, the framing effect on confidence has been successfully reproduced, albeit with the observation that the slope for the more frame remained relatively flat across the different baseline values (for mean confidence levels across different baseline conditions, see Figure S3 in Supplementary Material).
Next, to investigate the underlying cause of this effect, we have compared hierarchical linear regression models that assume the chosen-unchosen or diff-sum rules of confidence.

The models utilizing the chosen-unchosen rule demonstrated superior fit over those assuming the diff-sum rule according to AIC scores (Figure 3c). This result was also supported by model comparisons based on BIC scores (see Table B1 for AIC and BIC scores of all models). That is, the confidence framing effect, which has been experimentally observed as the summed value effect on confidence, is better explained through the lens of the chosen-unchosen rule (for further exploration on confidence rules, see Figure S4 in Supplementary Material).

The behavior of the winning chosen-unchosen model is encapsulated in its parameter estimates (Figure 3d). Opposite signs are assigned to the coefficients of chosen and unchosen values, meaning that the relative weighting between the two determines the confidence level. In the less frame, the chosen value was assigned a higher weight (β = -1.20, t(13.65) = -12.87, adjusted p < .001) compared to the unchosen value (β = 0.88, t(14.17) = 8.68, adjusted p < .001). Specifically, the value of the chosen stimulus plays a dominant role in shaping confidence, resulting in heightened confidence in the lower baseline condition, where the chosen stimulus has smaller values. The interaction between the chosen and unchosen values was also significant (t(3560.73) = 3.21, adjusted p = .004).

As expected, the coefficients in the more frame exhibited reversed signs compared to those in the less frame (e.g., under the more [or less] frame, higher confidence is associated with the larger [or smaller] chosen value). Of greater importance is nearly equal weighting assigned to the chosen value (β = 0.80, t(14.90) = 5.71, adjusted p < .001) and the unchosen value (β = -0.79, t(15.11) = -5.71, adjusted p < .001). This indicates that confidence was rather faithful to the difference between the log-transformed values of chosen and unchosen stimuli, which represent the ratio of two stimuli on the raw scale. This resulted in the flat pattern of confidence across the baseline conditions since the ratio of two alternatives was set constant across the baselines by considering Weber's law. We also found a small but significant 9 interaction between the chosen and unchosen values (t(3558.38) = 2.88, adjusted p = .012), indicating some synergistic contribution of the two underlying variables. Sepulveda et al. (2020) To ascertain the generalizability of our findings, we conducted additional analyses on previously reported data from Sepulveda et al.

div.head: Previously reported data from
div.p: , available at https://github.com/BDMLab/Sepulveda_et_al_2020. Here, we focused on their data from a 10 food choice task, where participants made two-alternative choices based on their food preferences (for additional analyses on their data from a perceptual dot discrimination task, see Figure S6 in Supplementary Material). Prior to their main experiment, participants underwent a bidding task on a food lineup, from which the subjective value of each food stimulus was calculated for each participant. In each of the main 2AFC trials, a pair of stimuli was presented with one being associated with a higher (or lower) subjective value referred to as a favorable (or unfavorable) option. Participants were required to choose a favorable option under a like frame, whereas they chose an unfavorable option under a dislike frame.

We performed regression analyses and model comparisons upon their dataset. Since no correlation was observed between the value difference and the summed value, we conducted the analyses using raw scale variables. For better model convergence, we standardized relevant variables (confidence, diff value, sum value, chosen value, and unchosen value) across all participants. Besides, to align the data with that from the perceptual task, we discarded trials in which the value difference was set at 0, as no correct answer is defined in such cases.

We first examined the probability of choosing the right-side stimulus by fitting psychometric functions as a function of the value difference, defined by subtracting the leftside value from the right-side value. The analysis was implemented as a hierarchical logistic regression with value difference, decision frame, and their interaction as fixed effects. The analysis also included value difference and decision frame as random slopes. As observed in our experiment, we found a strong interaction effect (z = 32.02, adjusted p < .001), which indicates the reversed slope between the decision frames (Figure 4a). Also, there was no significant difference in mean choice accuracy across participants between the like frame (74%) and the dislike frame (71.7%; χ 2 (1) = 2.93, adjusted p = .52), indicating the successful manipulation of decision frames (for further analyses of decision accuracy, see Appendix C).

Next, we conducted a hierarchical linear regression on confidence with summed stimulus value, decision frame, and their interaction as fixed effects. We also included random slopes for summed stimulus value and decision frame. The influence of the summed value on confidence was reversed across the decision frames (t(739.16) = 9.67, adjusted p < .001), which signifies the occurrence of the confidence framing effect (Figure 4b).

We compared the diff-sum and chosen-unchosen rules of confidence using the same 16 types of models described in Section 2.5. Model comparisons strongly favored the chosenunchosen models (like frame: best AIC = 8108.63; dislike frame: best AIC = 8772.76) over the diff-sum models (like frame: best AIC = 8226.49; dislike frame: best AIC = 8863.49; Figure 4c). Based on BIC scores, the chosen-unchosen rule also provided superior fit (like frame:
best BIC = 8175.44; dislike frame: best BIC = 8833.75) over the diff-sum rule (like frame:
best BIC = 8293.58; dislike frame: best BIC = 8930.58).

As expected, the signs of the estimated parameters of the best-fit chosen-unchosen models were reversed across the framing conditions. Under the like (or dislike) frame, higher confidence was associated with the larger (or smaller) chosen value (Figure 4d). Consistent with our main findings, the confidence framing effect in the preference task was also accounted for by asymmetric contributions of chosen and unchosen stimulus values. That is, under the like frame, the chosen value made a greater contribution to shaping confidence (β = 0.31, t(20.22) = 8.32, adjusted p < .001) compared to the unchosen value (β = -0. 21, t(27.32) = -4.05, adjusted p = .001). This explains the positive slope seen in Figure 4b, since the chosen stimulus value is higher for the trials with larger summed values, leading to greater confidence. Also under the dislike frame, the chosen value was assigned a larger weight (β = -0.47, t(26.04) = -6.01, adjusted p < .001) compared to the unchosen value (β = 0.11, t(13.75) = 3.48, adjusted p = .007), explaining the negative slope observed in Figure 4b.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Using the dot-number discrimination task, we investigated how decision frames modulate the construction of confidence. We found that the "choose more" and "choose less" frames led to different patterns of confidence rating, while decision accuracy remained unchanged (Figures 3b, 4b). This framing effect on confidence sheds light on the ongoing debate regarding whether confidence is grounded on optimal statistical norms or simpler heuristics (Adler & Ma, 2018;Aitchison, Bang, Bahrami, & Latham, 2015;Rahnev & Denison, 2018). Importantly, our experiment consisted of logically equivalent tasks under both decision frames. Accordingly, the observed pattern of confidence is unlikely to be explained by the normative account of confidence (Meyniel et al., 2015;Pouget et al., 2016;Sanders et al., 2016), which predicts the consistent confidence pattern for both frames. Thus, our results replicate the previous report of the confidence framing effect (Sepulveda et al., 2020) and provide supporting evidence for the heuristic view of confidence.

We found that the observed framing effect can be better explained by the chosenunchosen rule rather than the diff-sum rule of confidence (Figures 3c, 4c). Both of these rules involve heuristic computations, but they rely on different underlying variables that are distinguishable as to whether they consider the decision made by the observer (Figure 1).

Specifically, the chosen-unchosen rule allows asymmetric contributions from chosen and unchosen stimulus evidence (e.g., Maniscalco et al., 2016;Peters et al., 2017;Zawadzka et al., 2017;Zylberberg et al., 2012), which account for the occurrence of the confidence framing effect (Figures 3d, 4d).

One possible cause of this asymmetric weighting lies in post-decisional evidence accumulation (e.g., Pleskac & Busemeyer, 2010), allowing rather selective information gathering from the chosen stimulus (Navajas et al., 2016). However, recent research has raised a question on this perspective (Samaha & Denison, 2022), highlighting significant influences of pre-decisional processes in confidence formation (Shekhar & Rahnev, 2018;Xue, Zheng, Rafiei, & Rahnev, 2023). For instance, research has indicated that attentional allocation during pre-decisional evidence sampling plays a crucial role in shaping confidence 13 (Brus et al., 2021;Sepulveda et al., 2020). Consequently, there remains ambiguity concerning the specific mechanisms responsible for the asymmetric weighting of choice-congruent andincongruent evidence. Therefore, the present chosen-unchosen rule should be regarded as a descriptive model, simply explaining confidence as a weighted combination of chosen and unchosen evidence, which may be influenced by a variety of underlying processes.

One might assume that these confidence rules could closely resemble each other. For instance, assigning equal weight to chosen and unchosen values, with their signs reversed, may appear similar to the difference term in the diff-sum rule. However, the crucial difference lies in the chosen-unchosen rule's ability to differentiate between two representations:

subtracting the unchosen value from the chosen value and subtracting the chosen value from the unchosen value. Conversely, the diff-sum rule does not make this distinction and only focuses on the physical intensity of the stimulus (always subtracting the smaller value from the larger value). As a result, confidence is solely determined by physical stimulus intensity and cannot reflect the decision outcome (agnostic of trial-by-trial decision correctness).

It is worth noting that the diff-sum rule has been adopted in several previous studies to explain confidence in value-based decision (e.g., Brus et al., 2021;Folke et al., 2016; also see Mazor et al., 2023 for its application in a perceptual study). Our additional analysis, however,

showed that the chosen-unchosen rule provided a superior fit over the diff-sum rule even in the context of value-based decision. Interestingly, there has been a debate regarding the extent to which confidence in various cognitive domains originates from shared mechanisms (e.g., Fitzgerald et al., 2017;Michel & Peters, 2021;Morales et al., 2018). Thus, the present study would contribute important evidence to this discussion, suggesting the common confidence rule for perceptual and value-based decision-making.

In the dot discrimination task, confidence under the more frame was relatively constant across the baseline level, while confidence under the less frame showed a clear decreasing pattern (Figure 3b). Our experimental setup for the more frame has been closely tied with a phenomenon known as positive evidence bias. Typically, augmenting the absolute stimulus intensity while maintaining a constant signal-to-noise ratio results in increased confidence levels without affecting decision accuracy (e.g., Koizumi et al., 2015;Rausch et al., 2017;Samaha et al., 2016). This flat pattern of confidence was particularly evident in the dot discrimination task and was not pronounced in the food preference task (Figure 4b). This could be attributed in part to the online nature of the experiment, which might have led to somewhat noisy participant responses, potentially obscuring the underlying trend of increasing confidence. There might also be the involvement of non-numerical features that potentially obscure the increasing pattern of confidence. Some studies suggested that non-numerical features, such as dot density, can be involved in perceiving large numbers of dots (Anobile et al., 2015;Burr et al., 2018). The threshold at which these non-numerical features become relevant remains uncertain, and their potential impact on confidence will have to await future studies.

Another speculative cause of the flat confidence pattern is a potential increase in the subjective difficulty of counting larger numbers of dots; the expected rise in decision confidence might be counteracted by the increased perceived difficulty in counting. Note that our supplementary analysis showed that the error rate (i.e., objective difficulty in decisionmaking) decreased with the number of dots (see Figure S1). However, we assume here that the subjective difficulty of counting dots might increase with the augmentation of dot quantity.
In any case, these are mere speculations, and further study is required to settle this issue.

In addition, even in the food preference task, a stronger influence of the overall value on confidence was observed under the negative than positive frames (Figure 4b). Although the exact cause of this observation remains unclear, one speculative mechanism involves an amplified manifestation of confirmation bias. Confirmation bias is known as the tendency to gather information that supports one's existing belief or choice (e.g., Nickerson, 1998) and has been linked to the pronounced reliance on choice-consistent evidence in confidence formation (e.g., Michel & Peters, 2021). We speculate that this bias may intensify in decision-making scenarios where one selects an unfavorable option for elimination. To date, however, the influence of decision frames on confirmation bias has not been thoroughly explored, presenting an intriguing avenue for future investigations.

Here, it is important to acknowledge that our observation of the confidence framing effect appears to conflict with a previous recognition memory study (Miyoshi et al., 2018). They employed 2AFC recognition memory tasks, where participants had to choose either a memorized stimulus (old frame) or a novel stimulus (new frame) and report their confidence.

Importantly, regardless of the decision frames, confidence was primarily determined by the internal evidence of "oldness" for the stimulus judged as old. Namely, the confidence framing effect was not observed and higher confidence was consistently associated with a greater feeling of oldness in both frames.

We speculate that this apparent discrepancy between their study and ours can be attributed to the difference in the nature of the tasks: i.e., near-threshold detection vs. abovethreshold discrimination. Recognition memory judgment can be seen as a detection-like task,

where the observer aims to detect the "presence" of internal memory strength around the threshold for recognition (e.g., Snodgrass & Corwin, 1988). Presumably, in detection-like tasks, the observer can only attempt to detect the internal evidence of signal presence (which is the objective of the detection task), while no internal evidence can be formed for signal absence.

Even when the observer must choose the alternative of signal absence (new stimulus), they may still internally examine both alternatives for evidence of signal presence to determine which exceeds the memory strength threshold. This may explain why the confidence framing effect was not observed in Miyoshi et al. (2018).

On the other hand, for dot-number discrimination or preference choice tasks, the intensity for both target and nontarget stimuli would be well above the detection threshold. In this scenario, internal evidence for decision-making would be flexibly constructed in a goaldirected manner (e.g., evidence for "manyness" or "fewness") and made available for later processes, which could result in the occurrence of the confidence framing effect (see below for further discussion). Indeed, a recent neuroimaging study demonstrated that neural bases for confidence formation are different in visual detection and discrimination (Mazor, Friston, & Fleming, 2020), suggesting that somewhat distinct processes are involved in calculating confidence in these tasks. Taken together, the apparent discrepancy between our study and The goal-directed generation of decisional evidence is suggested by the results that the sign for the chosen-unchosen variables was reversed between the decision frames: e.g., chosen value was assigned positive (or negative) weight under the more (or less) frame (Figure 3b). As we have mentioned above, physical stimulus intensity would be transformed into internal evidence in a goal-directed manner, which is then used for decision-making and confidence construction. Under the more frame, physical stimulus intensity would be transformed into the internal evidence of "manyness", where the larger number of dots leads to the greater magnitude of internal evidence. Conversely, under the less frame, stimulus intensity is transformed into the evidence of "fewness", where the smaller number of dots produces stronger internal evidence. Namely, it is inferred that the goal-directed adjustment of information usage occurs at the stage of the physical-to-internal evidence transformation.
Accordingly, we consider that confidence derives from choice-contingent internal evidence constituted under specific cognitive goals, rather than stimulus values per se.

Previous studies have shown that asymmetric weights are placed on internal evidence for selected and unselected options (Maniscalco et al., 2016(Maniscalco et al., , 2021Peters et al., 2017;Samaha et al., 2017). However, it has yet to be proposed that this weighting occurs for goal-specific decisional evidence. From this perspective, a straightforward explanation would be offered for the framing effect on confidence. Under the less (or more) frame, evidence for the selected option refers to the internal degree of fewness (or manyness). Here, the smaller (or larger) stimulus value leads to stronger internal evidence of fewness (or manyness), which gives rise to greater confidence. In simpler terms, irrespective of the decision frames, stronger internal evidence for the selected option results in greater confidence. 1
This view is bolstered by a previous study of Miyoshi & Lau (2020), which highlighted the ecologically rational properties behind the greater weighting of chosen internal evidence.

They demonstrated that emphasizing chosen internal evidence leads to better metacognitive performance (Dayan, 2023;Fleming & Lau, 2014;Guggenmos, 2022;Maniscalco & Lau, 2012;Miyoshi et al., 2022) under real-world-like assumptions that internal evidence variance for the target stimulus is typically larger than that for the nontarget stimulus. This variance inequality arises primarily because the internal evidence distribution for the target stimulus has a greater mean and, consequently, greater variance due to the Poisson-like nature of neural firings (e.g., Kaernbach, 1991;Ma, 2010). The increasing variance of internal evidence as a function of its mean value has been supported in the long history of psychophysics (e.g., Green & Swets, 1966). Therefore, in the context of our less frame, the internal evidence of fewness exhibits higher variance for the target stimulus (i.e., stimulus of fewer dot numbers).

Then, by assigning greater weight to the internal evidence of fewness for the chosen stimulus, more accurate metacognitive monitoring can be achieved. In this way, the framing effect of confidence can be understood through the ecologically rational information heuristic utilized on goal-contingent decisional evidence.

Here, we would like to acknowledge that our perspective appears to be at odds with the recent findings of Boldt, Sun, & Desender, 2023. Their experiment involved the simultaneous presentation of eight stimuli with varying degrees of purplish colors, and participants answered whether the averaged color of the stimuli leaned more towards blue or red categories. The key finding from their investigation was the greater influence of choiceincongruent stimuli on participants' confidence levels. This observation was discussed in the context of the robust averaging model (De Gardelle & Summerfield, 2011), which assigns diminished weight to stimuli deviating further from the neutral category boundary. Namely, within the array of eight stimuli, the values associated with the chosen category were relatively distant from this boundary, and unchosen stimuli, positioned closer to the boundary, are endowed with relatively greater weight in confidence construction.

As previously discussed in their study, we see this apparent discrepancy between their study and ours stems from the dimensionality of internal evidence space. The task in Boldt, confidence. In contrast, we employed typical 2AFC tasks, where evidence from presented stimuli can be mapped onto a two-dimensional internal space, representing distinct evidence for S1 and S2. In this case, participants can separately assess the evidence from each stimulus and assign greater weight to chosen evidence when constructing confidence, which is shown to provide efficient metacognitive monitoring in multi-dimensional choice problems (Miyoshi & Lau, 2020). The advantage of this choice-congruent confidence formation may be limited to multi-dimensional choice situations and may not generalize to the one-dimensional task of Boldt, Sun, & Desender, 2023, thereby rationalizing the different confidence formation processes observed in our study and theirs. Ultimately, both our results and theirs can be seen as instances of efficient information processing occurring under distinct circumstances. Future studies are anticipated to provide further insights into rational information processing in the context of metacognitive monitoring.

Classic literature on the framing effect has often focused on the loss aversion phenomenon, a tendency for human observers to prioritize avoiding losses over acquiring equivalent gains (e.g., De Martino et al., 2006;Kahneman & Tversky, 1979;Tversky & Kahneman, 1981). Studies exploring this phenomenon typically involve framing conditions where the observer's choice results in the gain or loss of rewards. This contrasts with the framing examined in the current study, which simply oriented participants to choose the smaller or larger stimulus (preferable or unpreferable option) without involving explicit rewards.

Nevertheless, both of these framing research protocols share a common focus on the transformation of external stimuli into internal decision evidence (sometimes referred to as utility in the context of economic choices). Loss aversion is often attributed to the asymmetric shape of the transformation function, which emphasizes external information of losses over gains in deriving internal utility (e.g., prospect theory, Kahneman & Tversky, 1979). Similarly, as discussed above, the present confidence framing effect can also be explained through the mechanism that transforms the external stimulus value into internal evidence of manyness/fewness (or preferability/unpreferability). Manipulating task frames is a powerful approach to unravel the intricacies of the decision-making process, and additional research would be warranted particularly targeting the mechanisms underlying confidence formation.

Lastly, we would like to discuss a potential relationship between the neural mechanisms involved in constructing confidence and those responsible for representing goalguided internal evidence. The prefrontal cortex (PFC) is widely recognized as a locus of metacognitive monitoring (e.g., Fleming et al., 2010;Lebreton et al., 2015;McCurdy et al., 2013). For instance, studies reported that magnetic stimulation to PFC areas affects the observer's confidence level or metacognitive performance (Cai et al., 2022;Rounis et al., 2010;Shekhar & Rahnev, 2018). Besides, research suggests that PFC areas are responsible for representing internal evidence for decision-making, and the activity in these regions is reported to exhibit flexible modulation in response to specific task goals (e.g., Castegnetti et al., 2021;Hare et al., 2009;Rudorf & Hare, 2014). For example, Frömer et al. (2019) recorded functional magnetic resonance imaging BOLD responses from a so-called value network, encompassing the ventro-medial PFC and ventral striatum (Bartra et al., 2013), while participants made selections of consumer goods under choose-best or choose-worst frames.

The BOLD responses from the network were better associated with the goal-guided stimulus evidence rather than the objective stimulus value: here, goal-guided stimulus evidence was considered higher for the worst than best options under the choose-worst frame. These findings suggest that evidence formation under specific task goals (i.e., framing effect in deriving appropriate decision variables) and the subsequent construction of confidence partly share common bases at the cortical level. The flexible top-down modulation of metacognitive monitoring highlighted in the present study might be achieved through communication within the PFC network.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This study aimed to investigate the goal-directed modulation of metacognitive behavior.

Using the 2AFC dot-number discrimination task, we observed distinct patterns of confidence between the "choose more" and "choose less" frames, while decision accuracy remained unchanged. These findings challenge the normative account of confidence and thus provide supporting evidence for heuristic confidence formation. Our study highlights the goal-directed control in constituting decisional evidence, which would give rise to the confidence framing effect through the ecologically rational weighing of choice-congruent internal evidence. div.head: Appendix C
div.p: The present study reported the confidence framing effect, where the impact of the summed stimulus value on confidence was reversed between the decision frames. Here, one potential concern is that this observation could be mediated by the confounding effect of decision accuracy. Namely, higher confidence might be merely associated with conditions of greater decision accuracy.

To exclude this possibility, we tested whether the summed stimulus value had different effects on decision accuracy between the decision frames. For our dot discrimination data, we conducted a hierarchical logistic regression with the difference of log-transformed values, baseline value, decision frame, and their two-way interaction terms as fixed effects. The analysis also included the difference of log-transformed values, baseline value, and decision frame as random slopes. The results, summarized in Figure C1a and Table C1, revealed no significant interaction between baseline value and decision frame (χ 2 (1) = 0.13, adjusted p = 1), indicating rather constant effects of baseline value on decision accuracy under both frames.

Namely, under both frames, accuracy showed a slightly increasing trend as a function of the summed stimulus value. Therefore, the reversed pattern of confidence between the frames cannot be attributed to the confounding mediation of decision accuracy.

Next, for the previously reported preference-choice data, we conducted a hierarchical logistic regression with value difference, summed value, decision frame, and their two-way interaction terms as fixed effects. The analysis also included value difference, summed value, and decision frame as random slopes ( Figure C1b and Table C1). Again, no significant interaction was observed between summed value and decision frame ( χ 2 (1) = 0.0023, adjusted p = 1), ruling out the confounding mediation of decision accuracy in our observation of the confidence framing effect (for further analyses on accuracy, see Figure S1 in Supplementary Material).
